awd_titl_txt: Coupled Kinetic Physics of Protons and Electrons in the Solar Wind
awd_abstract_narration:
The problem of solar wind modeling has been of historical significance.  The related research is ongoing, and most models rely on macroscopic (fluid) models of the solar wind.  When kinetic effects, such as wave-particle interaction, are considered, however, the approach is usually not self-consistent in that certain types of wave turbulence is presupposed, and the wave spectra are modeled.  In contrast, the theoretical model to be developed as part of this three-year project will be fully kinetic and self-consistent.  This will significantly advance the knowledge in the field of heliospheric physics.  The model to be developed as part of this project will predict a particular state in which the solar wind plasma exists given a set of parameters, allowing the observed quantities to be tested against historic spacecraft data as well the planned measurements of the near-Sun environment that will be obtained by the Parker Solar Probe.  Although the present project is a theoretical one, rather than one involving data analysis, the resulting prediction may help experimentalists better interpret the past and future spacecraft data.  This has the potential to advance knowledge in a related, but different field of expertise, namely experimental heliophysics.

This three-year research project will investigate theoretically how the kinetic coupling of electrons and ions (protons) via collisional and instability processes affect the large-scale dynamics in the expanding solar wind.  The specific problem to be investigated relates to how the dynamically coupled solar wind electrons and protons contribute to the near isotropization of their temperatures -- an observed phenomena which has not yet been satisfactorily explained theoretically.  The PI's preliminary work based upon the assumption of bi-Maxwellian particle distribution shows that collisional process may be the dominant mechanism for the isotropization of temperatures, but the instabilities are important too for limiting the upper/lower bounds of temperature anisotropies. This project aims to extend the preliminary work by relaxing the assumption of bi-Maxwellian model in both instability analysis and collisional transport calculation.  The full kinetic equations for particles and waves, as well as the dispersion relation, will be solved by grid-based numerical scheme.  The collisional transport equation will also be solved by relaxing the assumption of bi-Maxwellian models.  Finally, the effects of inhomogeneities will be rigorously investigated by solving the macro-microscopic kinetic equation.

The research on the theoretical modeling of the solar wind is important from the broader perspective of understanding and characterizing fundamental processes that take place within the heliosphere and throughout the universe.  Discovering and understanding the basic physical processes in the immediate near-Earth environment and in the wider universe is essential for future human explorations of the universe, and it also has a space environmental impact, as the modern civilization is increasingly dependent on electromagnetic conditions in outer space.  Developing an accurate model of the solar wind contributes to such a wider goal. From the perspective of education and training, the present proposal involves a young post-doctoral research associate, which is a major strength in terms of Broader Impacts.  It is important for the healthy scientific future of our nation -- and the entire human society -- that a steady stream of young scientists are educated and trained in STEM disciplines.  The PI has in the past always strived to educate and widely disseminate the scientific knowledge acquired during his career to younger generation of scientists both from the U.S. and worldwide.  The present proposal will thus have a broader impact on the education and training of a young scientist.  The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The study of Sun's atmosphere, known as the corona, which is visible during the solar eclipse is an important contemporary science. The solar wind is an extension of the Sun's corona into the interplanetary space. The so-called corona heating problem is a long-standing issue. How the Sun's atmosphere attains millions of degree temperature from 4700 degree photospheric temperature is still being investigated, both by theoretical means and contemporary space missions (NASA's Parker Solar Probe and ESA's Solar Orbiter). A closely related aspect is that while the Sun's atmosphere immediately above the photosphere does not appear to have any organized motion, in the critical altitude at which the coronal heating take place (the transition region), the Sun's atmosphere suddenly exhibits an organized outward supersonic motion. This is the solar wind acceleration problem, which goes hand in hand with the coronal heating problem. Among the theories for explaining the twin problem of coronal heating and solar wind acceleration is that the pervasive electromagnetic turbulence that exists in the outer space, which is not visible to the naked eyes, yet can be detected by scientific instruments, plays a key role.

This NSF project is about how to mathematically describe such a turbulence. The turbulence in neutral fluids or air is well known, and can be experienced every time one turns out the bathroom faucet or fly in an airplane. The mathematical equation that describes such a turbulence is known as the Navier-Stokes equation, and it describes how the fluid or air moves. The electromagnetic turbulence is more complicated in that the gas is ionized. As a result, the Navier-Stokes equation must be solved together with the Maxwell's equations. Maxwell's equation describes how electromagnetic waves, such as the visible light, radio waves, infrared or ultraviolet radiation, X and gamma rays, are generated, absorbed and propagate in space. This NSF project developed mathematical models to describe the electromagnetic turbulence involving the ionized gas behaves in space and in time. The solar corona and the wind are made of ionized gas, and the turbulent motion of the ionized charged particles as they generate and absorb electromagnetic radiation is described by the mathematical model developed in this project. The mathematical model was tested against the computer simulation and was shown to be valid. In the future, the model developed in this project can be used to address the outstanding problem of how corona gets so hot and how the sun's upper atmosphere attains the supersonic speed. This is an ongoing effort, but the intermediate results obtained by the project have been published in peer-reviewed scientific journals.

The long impact of the research carried out in this project is not only important for intellectual reason, that is, to understand the long-standing question of why the sun's immediate surrouding environment is a thousand times hotter than it's surface, but it is important for practical reasons as well. Our sun is relatively benign when compared with other astrophysical bodies. Human beings also reside in the relatively narrow habitable zone from the sun. However, in the modern era of artificial satellite technology, the so-called space weather forecasting is an important ingredient of human society. The same mathematical model that describes the coronal heating and solar wind acceleration can eventually be applied to the space weather predicting endeavor. Sophisticated space weather prediction models are made of the said Navier-Stokes-like equation combined with Maxwell's equations, but the model is made of many sub units, among which is the coronal heating calculation unit. Even the most sophisticated space weather forecasting code use relatively simple and often empirical coronal heating models. The mathematical equation developed in this project is far more rigorous, which in principle, could be incorporated to the existing space weather tools. This is a future goal, but it is important to note such a long-term prospect in order provide a general sense of direction for future research.
